structural_lock_ins.activity_or_asset: EU Personal Data Processing and Cross-Border Transfers to U.S.
structural_lock_ins.locked_to_entity_or_jurisdiction: EU-based operations (Netherlands: Amsterdam data center, Germany: Frankfurt data center, UK: London data center) + Compliance with GDPR Article 46 transfer mechanisms
structural_lock_ins.legal_basis: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) + Schrems II decision (July 2020) invalidating EU-U.S. Privacy Shield + EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework (July 2023 adequacy decision, but under legal challenge). GDPR permits EU personal data to be processed in U.S. ONLY if: (1) Adequate transfer mechanism exists (Standard Contractual Clauses, Data Privacy Framework self-certification), AND (2) Case-by-case assessment confirms U.S. intelligence laws (FISA Section 702) do not impinge on data protection, AND (3) Supplemental measures implemented where necessary. Schrems II decision found that U.S. intelligence surveillance is incompatible with EU fundamental rights.
structural_lock_ins.operational_constraint: TOUCH TEST: If Rackspace consolidates EU and U.S. operations without maintaining GDPR-compliant transfer mechanisms, EU customers (estimated 20-30% of revenue = $300-450M) are IN BREACH of GDPR when using services. EU data protection authorities can impose fines up to 4% of global revenue ($60M based on $1.5B revenue) and order suspension of data transfers. If acquirer is subject to U.S. FISA Section 702 surveillance (e.g., large U.S. tech company), may be IMPOSSIBLE to maintain compliant data transfers under Schrems II precedent. CONSTRAINT TYPE: LEGAL + REGULATORY. Cannot freely transfer EU customer data to U.S. without compliant mechanisms. Cannot consolidate EU operations with U.S. cloud providers subject to broad surveillance. Must maintain EU-based infrastructure and operations to serve EU customers. EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework is under legal challenge (Max Schrems filed new cases February 2024) and may be invalidated like previous frameworks.
evidence_sources: CJEU Schrems II decision July 16, 2020: Invalidated EU-U.S. Privacy Shield due to U.S. intelligence surveillance laws
European Commission adequacy decision July 10, 2023: EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework adopted
Schrems legal challenges: February 2024 Ireland High Court approved participation in cases against Meta data transfers
EDPB Recommendations post-Schrems II: Case-by-case assessments required, cloud providers with access to data in clear may not be compliant
Rackspace data centers: Amsterdam, Frankfurt, London confirmed for EU operations
Rackspace blog: 'Data sovereignty: Keeping your bytes in the right place' acknowledges 100+ different data sovereignty regulations worldwide

structural_lock_ins.activity_or_asset: DoD and U.S. Defense Contractor Business (Impact Level 4 and Classified Work)

structural_lock_ins.legal_basis: DoD Instruction (May 2024 expansion): FOCI review process now applies to ALL U.S. government contractors performing unclassified contracts >$5 million (previously only classified contracts). 32 CFR ยง 2004.34 FOCI regulations require contractors to be free of foreign ownership, control, or influence OR implement FOCI mitigation measures (Special Security Agreements, proxy boards, etc.). U.S. government contracts requiring classified information access will NOT be awarded to companies under FOCI unless adequate safeguards are in place. Security clearances (Secret, Top Secret) require U.S. citizenship.
structural_lock_ins.operational_constraint: TOUCH TEST: If Rackspace is acquired by foreign entity (non-U.S. company or foreign private equity fund), IMMEDIATE FOCI DETERMINATION occurs. DoD contracts >$5 million (total DoD/government revenue unknown but material given 23 FedRAMP authorizations and service to >50% of cabinet agencies) become subject to FOCI mitigation requirements. Mitigation options: (1) Special Security Agreement with proxy board giving foreign owner NO operational control (defeats acquisition purpose), (2) Voting Trust Agreement segregating sensitive operations, (3) Divest DoD business entirely. FOCI mitigation is COSTLY, TIME-CONSUMING (6-12 months), and may be DENIED by DoD if foreign entity is from adversarial nation or has conflicting interests. Many foreign acquirers cannot meet FOCI requirements. CONSTRAINT TYPE: LEGAL + NATIONAL SECURITY. Cannot be acquired by foreign entity without triggering FOCI review. Cannot maintain current DoD business if foreign ownership creates unacceptable risks. May require structural separation of government business from commercial business (creates two separate companies).
